Comment: But in the great depression, people couldn't afford to buy anything at regular prices, and that drove trade collapse.   Today, income didn't take the first hit, trade did, so people who want to buy those things will simply have to pay more for them, and many will do so (some items will become simply unavailable, so people will go without or shift to pricier substitutes). It's a direct inflationary pressure. But once inflation kicks off even more, well now *most people* can't afford to buy anything.   They're similar events but since in this case we're self inflicting the economic pain with trade first, I don't think it's right to extrapolate that trade will continue a radical decline.  The same trade that won't happen at 100% tariffs also won't happen at 10000%.

Comment: They didn't ***hear*** it, because they had already tuned out the media it was being communicated through.  That's not the same thing as not ***caring***.  And if you think about it - you can see this.  Now - I voted for Harris. And I say that as someone who thinks she would have been a lousy president. I think she's be a few orders of magnitude \*less\* lousy, so she was my choice.  I also don't really blame her (much) for the failure to find functional avenues of communication to blue collar workers. She didn't have time.  However, the democrats certainly *did* have time to work on those avenues of communication. And they've done nothing since at least the early 2000's to correct this problem.  Ultimately, I see it this way.  * Republican voters have been conditioned to blame immigrants for everything and to be so angry at them that they can't think rationally * Democrat voters have been conditioned to blame republican voters (and this currently means blue collar voters) for everything and to be so angry at them that they can't think rationally * Neither of these perspectives survives objective scrutiny. Both are being foolish, regardless of who they vote for * The republican voters have been conditioned to blame and antagonize a relatively small percentage of voters * The democrat voters have been conditioned to blame and antagonize a relatively large percentage of voters * The democrat  Put it all together, and Democrats lose national elections when they point fingers.  I've also seen them win national elections when they make a coherent effort to reach blue collar workers and not antagonize them. I've legitimately never seen, in my lifetime, a democratic candidate lose a national election when this happens.  And I've never seen them win when it doesn't.  Harris didn't make a coherent effort because they was no time.  Personally, I believe she wouldn't have done it anyway, but... I'm not going to blame her when she never had the chance.

Comment: I did, and I don't disagree with their motivations. But pretending a hard decision doesn't have political fallout is naive.   There's also the meta point that he shouldn't have negotiated a deal that the *unions* would be happy with (because they didn't even get what they truly were after - sick leave), but forced the *rail companies* to take a little less in profit, which they had been raking in.   In doing so he also kneecapped the unions in future negotiations. The threat of a strike needs to be taken seriously, and the president and Congress stepping in on behalf of industries to preemptively break the strike is just another form of corporate welfare.   It's not surprising labor advocates and union members learned that Biden wasn't really on their side when push came to shove.
